senses.sense_definition: To write or compose a text, especially a literary or artistic work like a poem or letter.

examples.text: The author retired to his study to <w>indite</w> a new chapter of his novel.
She sat by the window to <w>indite</w> a heartfelt letter to her distant friend.

senses.sense_definition: To dictate words for someone else to write, or to prompt a specific sentiment.

examples.text: The king would <w>indite</w> his commands to the scribe standing beside him.
His heart seemed to <w>indite</w> a good matter, inspiring him to speak with passion.

senses.sense_definition: An archaic spelling of the verb <w>indict</w> (to formally accuse someone of a crime).

examples.text: In the old records, the magistrate <w>indited</w> the thief for stealing cattle.
The court decided to <w>indite</w> the man based on the evidence presented.

senses.sense_definition: To ask or invite someone to an event or place.

examples.text: The hostess wished to <w>indite</w> the guests to supper in the great hall.
He will <w>indite</w> his friends to join the celebration.

senses.sense_definition: An extremely rare mineral composed of indium, iron, and sulfur.

examples.text: The geologist was thrilled to find a specimen of <w>indite</w> in the rock sample.
Because <w>indite</w> is so rare, it is seldom seen outside of specialized collections.
